thread.title: Radio Waves: WINS-AM (1010) morning news anchor Brigitte Quinn can now add author to her list of ac¬ complishments.
thread.title_full: Radio Waves: WINS-AM (1010) morning news anchor Brigitte Quinn can now add author to her list of ac¬ complishments.

title: Radio Waves: WINS-AM (1010) morning news anchor Brigitte Quinn can now add author to her list of ac¬ complishments.
text:
WINS-AM (1010) morning news anchor Brigitte Quinn can now add author to her list of accomplishments. 
Quinn's first novel, "Anchored," was recently released by Curtis Brown Unlimited. 
The book, based on Quinn's years working in television, follows a female anchor whose dream is to become the next Barbara Walters, and what happens with the arrival of her new male co-anchor. 
"I think anyone who listens to WINS and wonders what it's like behind the scenes in any news organization would appreciate reading the many scenes set in the newsroom. The story's also set in New York City in the early 2000s, so I think listeners will also appreciate the memories of those turbulent times," Quinn said. 
Quinn has worked in broadcasting for more than 30 years, and was a television anchor at the Fox News Channel, MSNBC and NBC. She holds an MFA in writing from Sarah Lawrence College and a BS from Cornell University. 
"Writing a novel was certainly a challenge for someone who's used to slamming out copy and avoiding adjectives, to write the sort of long-form, descriptive narrative necessary for novel writing," said Quinn, who lives in Connecticut with her husband and three children. "But it was also fun. And working in noisy newsrooms for so many years definitely helped me tune out the chaos at home." 
The book sells for $13.99. To learn more visit brigittequinn.com. 
* 
The Historical Society of Rockland County will host on-air personality Dennis Elsas in a multimedia experience at 8 p.m. Saturday at Rockland Community College in Suffern, N.Y. 
As one of the pioneers of the progressive FM radio revolution at WNEW-FM (102.7), Elsas will share his favorite stories and experiences — including highlights from his interviews with rock legends John Lennon, Elton John and Jerry Garcia. 
The college is at 145 College Road. 
Tickets are $25. Information: 845-574-4244 or rocklandhistory. org. 
* 
WFMU-FM (91.1), the New Jersey-based independent station, has received a $100,000 grant from the Geraldine R. Dodge Foundation in support of Audience Engine, the station's new audience development and fundraising software. 
WFMU has teamed with Bocoup, a software developer based in Boston, to create Audience Engine, a publishing tool built to empower media institutions to broadcast, publish and fund-raise in the digital age. 
Through its subsidiary Congera, WFMU will make the new open-source digital platform available for free to public broadcasters and to print and digital news organizations. 
Congera will also offer hosting services for content makers who prefer an off-the-shelf, hosted alternative for the Audience Engine platform. Congera also secured its first round of private investment for its hosting venture, raising $195,000 from a handful of private investors.The Dodge Foundation was an early supporter of the Audience Engine, which was developed by WFMU based on tools it uses on its own website. 
* 
STATION BREAKS: WKXW-FM's (101.5) Big Joe Henry will broadcast from the New Jersey Natural Gas Asbury Park Boardwalk Studio, Third and Fourth avenues, Asbury Park, for the Seventh Annual Asbury Park Zombie Funeral/Walk from 10 a.m. to 3 p.m. Saturday … NPR's Michel Martin spent the past year traveling across the country hosting a series of live events. Beginning Saturday, she brings her brand of journalism back to the studio and to social media, as weekend host for "All Things Considered." Martin came to NPR in 2006 and launched "Tell Me More," a one-hour daily NPR news and talk show that aired on NPR stations nationwide from 2007 to 2014 … WDHA-FM (105.5) will broadcast live from Ramapo-Bergen Animal Refuge Inc.'s Pitbulls and Pumpkins Fall Festival between noon and 4 p.m. Sunday. RBARI is at 2 Shelter Lane in Oakland. Information: rbari.org or wdhafm.com. 
Email: edel@northjersey.com.
